Okay, so I don‚Äôt know why this is the ‚ÄúDefinitive Edition‚Äù when it‚Äôs Early Access, nor why if it‚Äôs definitive you can still buy the non-definitive one, and anyone trying to get answers out of these developers is frankly barking up the wrong tree. That‚Äôs a confusing thing that doesn‚Äôt make any sense to me, but that‚Äôs OK, that‚Äôs fine, it‚Äôs not something to get all catty about. And I don‚Äôt want to just make jokes about furries here, because that‚Äôs cheap and doesn‚Äôt say anything about the game or the problems it has that are fundamentally there regardless the whole business of day-glo ferrets hobbling about the place. For example, these guys decided to make their visual novel in RPG Maker, which means that it uses a lot of CPU and also the options menu offers such useful features as auto-run and the ability to remember which action you last used in combat which are all very useful in this tedious choose your own adventure bull-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. The first thing that happens is some dog thing with implausible colors spouts off a silly tail about mysticism or alternate worlds or something, then you wake up on a train with the largest seats in the world. I thought that since you‚Äôre there with a squirrel maybe the player character is just really tiny, but it turns out that the Japanese just love to scurry about underneath their stupidly massive seats while riding the bullet train. Then you meet ROOK T OVERFERRET, who you can also befriend on Steam because he is a terrible self-insert among a whole cast of self-inserts. Self-insert writing is bad regardless of whether or not you make yourself a big animal person who is so sexy that he used to be Japan‚Äôs premiere male host in their most famous maid caf√© and the developer gets to be the world‚Äôs most famous pop star of course and is a silly dog with rainbow hair and i can't ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing take it anymore I don‚Äôt like this game it‚Äôs got a bunch of choices that don‚Äôt really matter it‚Äôs got awful writing the characters are horrible and annoying and they are all designed like they fell into a paint factory and the game is a scam, it‚Äôs literally a scam, how the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• is it definitive if it‚Äôs early access why is the original still for sale, take it down or something or just rename it what was the point of this why is it even here and why did you make your game in rpg maker just use renpy or twine it‚Äôs not hard come ON dude shape it UP also I ran out of animal puns I‚Äôm sorry

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

I do not see the need for duplicate co-existing titles being updated simultaniously in my library.
This one should have kept to being released once the story is done, do yourself a favour, and buy the original MM instead and get both (unsure if buying this will grant the original at this time, even if I don't think it should even be released already).

This serves no purpose at the time of writing, sadly enough, and thus I cannot in all honesty recommend it.

The entire *purpose* of the Definitive Edition was to give a full game to people who didn't want to wait for each episode of the episodic original. Provide the full story. This Early Access episodic release defies it's singular point of existence/purpose in that manner.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

I've had experiences with both the original and this new version of the game, writing this review on the release the game is still somewhat of a mess, the lines used in the screenshots and description are misleadingly selected and quite untrue upon experiencing the game. So far the changes made seem to make the story even more of an all over the place mess and some of the backgrounds being used now are very unfitting and silly (First scene on the subway for example, giant chairs?).

This game does have a rather nice soundtrack, character art and it is not unenjoyable if you don't try to take it to seriously, if you are deadset on playing the game I would advise doing it with a group of friends, each reading a character as I have done this in the past and it made the game a whole lot more fun. And I have to give credit to the developer for making this version of the game free to those who own the base game.

To sum up, it's not really a good game, but it's not godawful either in my opinion.

If you are walking into this game wanting an idea of what the furry fandom is or to learn about furry culture this game gives absolutely no experience of those topics, it is simply a story that takes place using fursonas belonging to members of the furry fandom.

I don't want to start any drama, buy the game, don't buy the game, it's up to you, but to me it is still a rather bad game on it's own, and I wouldn't recommend buying it at this point in time, but who knows? It's still in early access after all, and the developer really does seem to be listening to fans. For better or for worse.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early Access Watcher Reviews Major / Minor - Definitive Edition (EA)

Update Version: Initial EA release

Disclosure: This game copy was bought by the reviewer.

Disclaimer: As of right now there are two products on the market with this content, but no clear explanation for it. The developer has stated on the discussion board he has a explanation for this and will have it posted in the near future.


Special Note Edit: I had stated in the previous version of this review that crashes were a concern. On inspection it was a faulty download on either Steam's part or a faulty install to the drive on my end. I let the game run and retested the parts the game crashed at and have not had an issue since.


I will take the opportunity to use my introduction paragraph as a disclaimer for what I hope the reader to expect in the coming review. I am no way affiliated with the anthropomorphic community nor do I understand the terminology used by them on a daily-basis. I am not knowledgeable in the least about what a fursona is or the stereotypes used by them, but I do understand the usage of a stereotype and the tropes established by them. This review will not focus on the insertion of the real people apparently using these characters in everyday life or of the scandal I researched that took place with the original release which I have not played. All I plan to do with this review is determine from the bugs, cliches and story structure if it is a recommended product to pick up at the current interval at the current asking price. That said, I will begin with the most important issue: artwork.

Visual novels are usually known for their wide variety of artwork and character models, but in this case the art was left at the curve. Backgrounds are slightly faded pictures of random locations while character models are stuck with one pose (two if you count switching the facing direction). The only person who had more than one pose was named Eclair, a cafe maid feline you meet along one of the branching paths. This would have made it very difficult to follow dialog, but thankfully a character portrait is placed next to the text box to designate who was speaking. The actual artwork was decent, but I will say some of the designs left me trying to figure out the gender of a certain character. This is not a fault or a pro, it is just a little observation. The music was rather pleasant, so I do commend the audio wizards for that.

One factor I will consider a fault is the off the wall pacing and stereotypical characters. The story was not hard to understand, thanks to very minimal spelling errors and grammar issues, but the structure was throwing out random monologues in one direction and character backstory in another. You have the main conflict discussed, but some elements are introduced and fall of the face of the earth to never be discussed again. It would not be an issue if the characters were not so stereotypically written. Each character has a forced cliche approach, which feels stale and plain boring to read when the dialog comes from such sterile personalities. I felt the urge to skip most of the character monologues on several occasions just for this reason alone.

The branching paths determined by dialog selections does have an impact in certain situations. Two of the choices very early in the game will allow you to meet a certain character while others will open additional character arcs for the reader to experience. Thankfully, the game provides very ample opportunities to save, even if the amount of available save slots is restricted to 20 right now. Actual outcomes are up for interpretation. I played through the game three times to try and get an idea of how different the outcomes can be, only to discover the story follows the same general direction. The people who die are still the same and the events that you are involved with are still the same. Maybe it will change once the rest of the story is released, but for now it is really is just a cosmetic feature.

As I mentioned in the opening paragraph, this is not a judge of the actual story of the elements surrounding the content (except for the stereotyping). Most of the problems stem from a disjointed flow. It took me about 2 hours to get through the first playthrough and four hours total play time with all three playthroughs. For the price, I would say it is a little light. This will hopefully change down the line, but at this point I cannot recommend the product. As per my policy, I will return to this visual novel sometime in the future to reevaluate it and hopefully change my initial opinion.

Pros

- Spelling and grammar is up to par
- Soundtrack was decent

Cons

- Stereotypical characters
- Very erratic and out of tone pacing
- 2 hours to get through a play through

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

(A review copy was issued to me after the purchase of the previous store version.)
After revisiting this game after several months. I can safely say that this game has changed for the better. and has made my entire last review almost irrelevant.

For a quick overview.
Is the game good?"
Well
date:
that is subjective.
Let me answer that with more questions.

Do you Enjoy Furries
recommended:
or at least their Anthro counterparts?
Do you Enjoy a Visual Novel experience?
Do you Enjoy a Visual Novel where your choices define who you are and what path you choose?
Do you Enjoy Murder Stories?
Do you Enjoy Japanese Sub culture?
Do you Enjoy Fantasy Worlds?
If you answered yes to most of those than you have a high Likelyhood of enjoying this game.

My initial impression of it was.. bad to say the least (1rst CH.) but it has come a long way.
My new scores are as follow. (As of CH.5 release)

Music 8/10
The Music has gotten a Re-vamp
hoursPlayed: No longer do I hear ANY stock music
voteText:
it seems to be all costom made for the VN.
and it can be quiet addictive to hum or sing after a playthrough.
I can Only hope they release the V-CD so I can download these to my phone.
Though your milage may vary as I have a taste for said genre of music.

Gameplay 8/10
I decided to bring this down to an Eight instead of a nine after reconsideration. Even though I believe the gameplay (for a visual novel) is superb! BUT I also think it could have some improvements

votesTotal:
the game still is worthy of the Score.

Story 9/10
Even though I am not partial to these sort of stories
votesFunny: it really drew me in. Be it the side stories
commentsCount:
or the main story itself. Human curiosity makes me always want more. There's not much else I can say without spoilers.

Character 8/10
The characters this time around are less stereotypical and more
column17:
Life like?
They are far more fleshed out and even make me care about people that might not even matter in the overall arch of the story.. and I say Might as.. I cannot tell who is background and who is not. which is a achievment any VN developer should strive for.

Character designs 8/10
Now
column18:
I have my personal feelings on some of these. As there are less than a handfull that stick out like sore thumbs.
As they just look too Animated to fit in with the rest of the cast. And have a real (OC) feel to them.
Which I personally see as a con. That is why I marked it down two points. Other than that Most characters fit in the world they are in and can at times make me forget they are not human.

Writing 9/10
The writing feels very professional since I last saw its dilapidated form..
And now is on par with most reading material you would see in a Succesful book.
I have yet to find a typo or a missused word.
And the Vocab

which I honestly see as a plus)

Choices 8.5/10

And some of the choices even let you describe yourself

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Notice I have not finished the game yet I will update this review when I have.

Major/Minor is an anthropomorphic visual novel game that is intertwined by two worlds and you have the power to decide the fate of those worlds.

The story is very well written and the characters were designed wonderfully with there looks and personalities, the music in the game was composed great also it feeds to the atmosphere of the game for what is happening in the moment and beginging of the scene.

The game has the choice mechanic were your able to choose your own path and the game has multiple endings so replay value is very high within this game

I have not finished the game I am getting to the point of the game where the story is starting to pick up and at the same time getting very interesting,The story keeps me guessing on what is going to happen next while I am guessing I myself are making theories before I get to a certain point within the game

Now this game dose have some faults in it but can easily be forgiving.

In new scenes the music and sound lags for a few seconds or at times for a minute but it quickly fixes itself, I do wish there was a save button to save when ever you want some of the scenes are very long before you get to a save point (if there is a save button forgive me if i have not found it.)

Things id like to see implimented into the game.

Id love to see the sprites have motion the details of the sprites are done superb but I think the experience in the game would be more thrilling to have the sprites have motion.

Also id love to have voice acting implimented into the game I just would love to hear the characters have voices of there own to give them somthing more to who they are and to add to the atmosphere.

Id also love to have more sound effects implitmented into the game to add to the scenes and atmophere when somthing is happening.

Over all I love the game very much its well written and very detailed I cannot wait to finish the story, this is a wonderful visual novel game that would be a great addtion to your collection even if you dont like antrhopomorphic's the story is worth the play time.


I hope this review was helpful to anyone who may be interested in the game.



~Bloodwolf

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok here goes.

Major/Minor is a furry visual novel that I find to  be quite enjoyable. From the loveable characters to the suspenseful plot there is definitely something to be had here. I played this game back when it was a free beta and remember my excitement when i first heard the menu music playing. For me music like that is a promise. A promise for something great and fantastic and an adventure that will keep me enticed from start to finish.

[Now i know what you're saying, But why does it say it's a complete edition if it is early access??? That doesn't make any sense!!!"

Well that is because the developer of the game
recommended:
is not entirely finished yet. It is stated in the description if you want anymore info. If you are reading this part of the review and the game is already complete then please disregard.]
.
.
.
Characters: Every single character in the game has depth and feeling. When I interacted with them I identified them with a lot of real world people I know. The character Kila for example reminds me of a really close friend that I used to have. That sense of familiarity really does influence how you will go about playing the game since every one in it feels pretty genuine.
.
.
.
Gameplay: In traditonal visual novel fashion you have the ability to make choices that influence how the game will end. This is very reminicent of the Visual Novel Morenatsu
hoursPlayed:
another furry novel. It's very interesting to have a game that actually takes your choices into account rather than just carrying the illusion of choice like most triple A games today. Some characters respect or hate you for the game duration based on what you say or do. Really gives the player a sense of immersion.
.
.
.
Soundtrack: Music is a huge selling point for me as stated above. Boy does the game deliver on that aspect. I was really captured by the entire score while I was playing because it set the right mood. Nothing about it was under used or overdone. My hats off to the composer who treated this game and the atmosphere it portrayed with care.
.
.
.
Final thoughts: Overall this is a very repectable game and a wonderful entry into the gaming scene for Klace. It manages to capture a world of his own design perfectly and rarely misses a beat. While it may not be my absolute favorite game of all time it still deserves a purchase and some recognition for what it conveys here. As a furry or someone trying to get into the community you owe it to yourself to play this game.
.
.
.
10/10 already playing again. <3"

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

NoteI'm not putting much time into this version till the story for the base version is complete. My review is valid up to Chapter 4 release, beyond that may come off as out dated. Here is my original review from the base game with hours showing I have played it, while also copy pasting the text here for convinence.

I do plan to write a whole new review ONCE the story is finished, but instead for the base game I'll make a new one for this version.

General Disclaimer
This is a Visual Novel. There is no gameplay other than click to read and make choices that will present to you. If you're expecting this to be an RPG of some kind, you're sadly mistaken.

If you find heavy text boring and complain like, ‚ÄúIt's just enter, read text, enter, read text, enter, read text...‚Äù you‚Äôre better off avoiding all Visual Novels and sparing your sanity along with sparing people from hearing you whine about what the game actually is suppose to be.

If you‚Äôre disgusted at the sight of anthro characters, well if you buy this game and complain, you‚Äôll most likely be seen as a whiner for wasting your own money and time on a product you knew yourself wouldn‚Äôt like.

Review
I‚Äôve been following this VN since the month it was released. At the time of this review, there are 4 chapters out. Upon one chapter after another I was getting more and more glued into it. I even made a guide regarding the choices you may see and what effects they‚Äôll have later on down the round in your playthrough. (Warning: My guide may have minor spoilers.)

There are two stories being told: One on Earth, another on Terra. They have no direct connection with one another and I find this format very unique to me and interesting. There are at least 2 plots going on with a possible third, or so I like to believe.

Every character stands out differently from one another. The music fits in with the mood nicely and well timed with the text. Choices prompted up may trigger another one later or cause an alternate route to some degree (note my guide). You may find yourself thinking hard of what to pick whether it‚Äôs moral or philosophical to you on some choices.

There are a few things to note:
There are no expressions (however en route at this time). It is normal or common for VN‚Äôs to have character expressions to help the reader feel more immerse to the story and the world, but this didn‚Äôt have them initially. I wasn‚Äôt at all bothered by this, but a lot found it unease or immersion breaking.
There is no voice acting.
The VN is episodic; despite it might feel it‚Äôs Early Access. There is currently no steady schedule for chapters after people wanted expressions so badly. There will be delays in new chapters arriving for quite some time.
The VN is for the general audience with the occasional minor violence it portrays time to time. If you‚Äôre expecting fan service, go to Sakura series or Nekopara vol 1 and 2 (you‚Äôre welcome in advance).
You can‚Äôt save freely, only when prompted. However, you may see them before or after a serious choice is prompted or a serious moment happened. They are far in between, however.
At this time I would say wait for a sale unless you have the money to spare for the full price, or till all chapters are out.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nOnce again I just need to say, the ability to make me experience such powerful emotions through only static portraits and a dialogue box is the mark of a great writer. I was legitimately shouting at my screen during several portions, while tearing up at others. The struggle these characters go through is immense, and the story isn't even done yet. I just hope we get a happy ending with no Game of Thrones BS. The best character and fan favorite is Konrad the Assassin. #shipping

reviewText:
A Masterpiece so far in story telling, Five Chapters in and ever single time leaves me hanging on the edge wanting more

Some of the backgorunds makes the text hard to read since most the backgrounds have a Blurr effect.

I really hope the dev follow through with all 12 Chapters...  Klace better not die in real life before the game is finished... (possible spoiler alert)

On a side note this isn't a dating sim style... The story appreses to be as dark as hateful boyfrined AND  THAT WAS NOT, NO WERE CLOSE TO A DATING SIM... That was a very dark and twisted story/game.. I loved it

8/10 (now only if the backgrounds were not blurred)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I wasn't really expecting to be one to review this? Guessing it's luck, but overall my original review still kinda stands, except I guess I have a bit more to add.

Now while most of the stuff is the same, (atleast from what I could tell) I thought that the game seemed to be running a lot smoother, although it may have been my computer. I'm not quite sure if new facial animations have been added, as there were times when it looked like it was trying to change the sprite, but I'm not entirely sure as it could be my computer (My computer really sucks basically). Another small problem I had was it felt like the first two chapters were a bit too short and the third one felt extremely long, and a majority of the 3rd chapter was text for the most part.

However something good did come out of it, as I have never been on such a mental and emotional rollercoaster like this before. It left me questioning a lot of my choices sort of like a more choice heavy Undertale, and for the most part I enjoyed it, especially some of the writting as most of it left me questioning some of my choices a lot, and now I'm beginning to even question who's the good guy and who's the bad guy.

Overall, I'd still recommend it, though I'm not really sure if it's at it final stage of development yet, but if you're not really sure about, you can always just refund it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe developer is now in my good books. Klace re-branded his episodic game as Early Access, launched a Definitive Edition and gave it to all existing and future customers of the original title for free. It's not so often you see a selfless action like this in the greedy world of game development. He easily could have charged more for the new version. Thanks, man. More will follow about the story in an edit as I had a review on the old store page as well.

Early Access Review

I have two things to say about this game:
1. I rate it 10/10, GO BUY IT NOW!!
2. Even if you're not a furry, you can still play this game. Trust me, the story is centered around about life and death, and about the choices you make in the game. It's amazing!
It's totally worth the $10.
